title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) — On a night when basketball felt less like a team sport and more like a personal showcase, the Houston Rockets did not defeat the Cleveland Cavaliers. Hakeem Olajuwon did.

In a breathtaking display of individual dominance, Olajuwon powered the Rockets to a 107-89 victory, authoring a performance for the ages that left the Cavaliers grasping at shadows. The final score was a mere formality; the real story was the 42 points etched next to the Dream’s name.

From the opening tip, it was clear Olajuwon was operating on a different plane. He was an unstoppable force in the painted area, a whirlwind of spin moves, drop-steps, and his signature fadeaway jumper. The Cavaliers had no answer. Triple-teams were navigated, double-teams were rendered useless, and any single coverage was nothing more than an invitation to score. His 42 points were not just a number; they were a systematic dismantling of an entire defense.

While Clyde Drexler provided crucial support with 19 points and 7 rebounds, and Mario Elie dished out 8 assists, this was Olajuwon’s symphony. He was the conductor and the soloist, commanding the floor and dictating the tempo of a game that was never truly in doubt.

For the Cavaliers, the night was a frustrating exercise in futility. Despite a valiant 23-point effort from Terrell Brandon and a double-double from Shawn Kemp, they were merely spectators to history. They were not beaten by a system, but by a singular, monumental force of nature wearing number 34.

In the annals of the game, where great performances are remembered, this one will stand tall. It was a night Hakeem Olajuwon looked every defender in the eye and showed them what greatness looks like, one impossible basket at a time.
